rounds.observation:
[GAME] You are Player 0 in a 2-player Texas Hold'em Poker game.
Your goal is to win chips and outlast opponents through masterful play.
Game Information:
- 10 hands total
- Starting stack: 1000 chips
- Blinds: 10/20

Before making a decision, first generate relevant poker knowledge that applies to your current situation.

Generate Knowledge: What key poker principles, mathematical concepts, psychological insights, position strategies, betting patterns, or tournament tactics are most relevant to your current situation?

After generating this knowledge, apply it to evaluate your options and make your decision.

Available actions (exact tokens):
  '[Check]'  - when no bet is live
  '[Call]'   - match the current bet
  '[Fold]'   - discard your hand
  '[Bet N]'  - open for N chips
  '[Raise N]'- raise by N chips

Invalid actions will result in retries. Use exact bracket format and ensure you have sufficient chips for bets/raises. Check when facing a bet is invalid.
[GAME] Starting a new 10-round Texas Hold'em game with 2 players.
[GAME] ===== Hand 1 / 10 - Pre‑flop =====
Pot: 30 | Current bet: 20
Visible board: []
P0 (Dealer/BB): 990.00 chips | bet 10.00 | active
P1 (SB): 980.00 chips | bet 20.00 | active
Your hole: 3♦, 7♠
==============================================
rounds.response:
Generate Knowledge:
- Heads-up ranges & equity: From the big-blind with 35-off, raw equity vs a wide small-blind range is only ~37 %.  
- Pot odds: Villain has laid 20 chips; calling costs 10 more into a 30-chip pot → immediate pot odds 3:1 → need roughly 25 % equity to break-even. Our ~37 % equity meets this threshold.  
- Position: No post-flop position hurts because we’ll act first on every street. For speculative hands, realizing equity is therefore harder.  
- Stack-to-pot ratio (SPR): Effective stack 980 ; pot pre-call = 30, so SPR after a call would be 980 ÷ (30+10) = 24.5 — very deep, implying a small call is inexpensive relative to stacks.  
- Ranging: SB heads-up opens a wide, virtually any-two type range; our holding blocks less of a strong part of that range.  
- Tournament survival: 10-hand match, blinds tiny, so chip preservation is not yet critical; however discipline vs garbage hands remains important.  
- Outcome profiles:  
  – Folding costs 0 and forfeits 10 already posted, keeps initiative low.  
  – Calling 10 retains maximum stack depth but risks playing out of position with a very weak hand.  
  – Raising creates additional risk without a strong hand; 3-bet from SB would likely force us to fold after investing more.  

Evaluation:
1. Pot odds easily justify a call if we could play perfectly post-flop.  
2. But post-flop OOP complexity and reverse-implied odds (weak one-pair, A-high boards, dominated flushes) significantly depress our realized equity.  
3. Deep effective stacks amplify the importance of skill edge; without read on opponent, cautious approach is prudent.  
4. Raising (building a pot with 3-7o OOP) is clearly –EV.  

Decision: Fold the junk. Sacrifice the 10 chips already wagered rather than risk off-suit trash OOP.

[GAME] Player 0 attempted an invalid move. Reason: Invalid poker action. Please resubmit a valid move and remember to follow the game rules to avoid penalties.
rounds.response:
Generate Knowledge:

1. Starting hands 3♦7♠ from the big-blind (OOP) vs a single opponent → this combo is in the bottom 15 % of all Hold’em hands.  
   - Hot-and-cold equity vs a 100 % range is ~36 % at best.  
   - Flops poorly (rarely makes straights or flushes; top-pair is weak).  

2. Action recap:  
   - Pot = 30 (our 10 BB already posted).  
   - Effective extra to call = 10 chips (call 20 total – we’ve already put in 10).  
   - Pot-odds = 10 / (30 + 10) = 25 %.  
   - Reverse-implied odds are bad because we’ll often hit second-best hands and lose additional chips post-flop OOP.

3. Tournament context:  
   - 10-hand sprint; survival value slightly elevated vs chip accumulation early.  
   - Future blinds increase relative to stacks—avoid bloating pots with marginal holdings.

4. Psychological/game-flow insight: Heads-up pre-flop, many players raise wide from SB; anything above ~40 % would include our hand in an equity-deficit situation. We cannot profitably defend 3-7o for 25 % of the pot with this reverse-implied-odds profile.

Decision:
We are facing a bet of 20; our options are [Call] or [Fold]. [Check] is invalid.

Expected value of calling is negative once reverse-implied odds are considered; folding minimizes chip bleed and keeps future spots exploitable.

[Fold]

rounds.response:
Generate Knowledge:  
Hand range theory (in heads-up, play about 50%-60% of hands).  
Position matters greatly: I’m in the big blind, out of position post-flop.  
Effective stack is 990 vs 980 ≈ 49 BB.  
Pre-flop, the pot is 30 and a 20 bet is already in front of me — the decision is to call 10 more or fold.  
Hand equity: 3♦ 7♠ is offsuit, one-gapped, very low—its hot-cold equity is only ~34 % vs a random hand but drops quickly vs realistic defending ranges. Modern solvers suggest big-blind defend vs a 3 BB open (effectively this) requires ~55–60 % VPIP; this combo falls into the bottom of that range (usually >60 % defend for offsuit). 3♦ 7♠ has reverse implied odds: when we hit a 7 or 3 we often get outkicked and when we make a straight it’s the lower end. Our implied odds are shallow (stack ≈49 BB). Add to the out-of-position disadvantage; we risk being pushed off hands or having to play large pots without clarity.

Recommendation: Fold the junk hand and look for better spots.  

Action: [Fold]
